awd_titl_txt: Research on the Thermal Correction System and Thermal Coating Noise
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced LIGO is a gigantic laser interferometer that is likely be the first instrument to detect gravitational waves. Opening this completely new window to the universe is one of the most anticipated scientific events in the near future. But Advanced LIGO will only be successful if it is possible to compensate and correct all static and dynamic radii of curvature errors in all optical components inside the instrument. These curvature errors would otherwise reduce the contrast inside the interferometer, increase the losses and the noise, and limit the reach of Advanced LIGO. These curvature errors will be caused by manufacturers who have limited control over the surface figure during polishing and coating of the optics and by thermal gradients inside the optics which will be caused by residual laser beam absorption. The thermal compensation system (TCS) is responsible for measuring and correcting these errors. The TCS uses ring heaters around each mirror to change their radii of curvatures and a laser projection system to write a specific heating pattern into the optic to compensate the thermal lens inside the substrate. This award supports a small testbed to develop and test the TCS, analyze the requirements to be imposed on the TCS, and train students on this important subsystem. Advanced LIGO will be limited by the Brownian motion of the atoms which form the dielectric coatings of the mirrors inside the interferometer. Although the theory of coating thermal noise is well established, the magnitude of such noise depends on several less well understood material parameters. Direct measurements of the noise are rare, hardly systematic, and have never been done across the Advanced LIGO frequency band. This award will also support an experiment dedicated to measure thermal coating noise for different coatings, substrates, and different beam sizes to study thermal coating noise in great detail and across the entire Advanced LIGO frequency band.

The importance of the detection of gravitational waves for astrophysics and astronomy can hardly be overestimated. These waves are caused by moving masses which change the curvature of spacetime. This change propagates through space in the form of gravitational waves. These waves are a direct consequence of the speed limit in the universe and their exact form is described by Einstein's theory of general relativity. Opening this completely new window to the universe will allow study of the physics behind many interesting astronomical objects such as neutron star or black hole binaries or supernovae. However, the experimental challenges to reach the expected sensitivity present an ideal training ground for graduate students and young scientists. These students will gain valuable skills by working on a small but challenging laboratory experiment within the context of Advanced LIGO.

por.por_cntn:
All our activities and outcomes of our project were related to advanced LIGO (aLIGO) and potential future upgrades of aLIGO. LIGO is a ground-based gravitational wave observatory with two coincidence detectors in the US. These detectors are 4km long Michelson interferometers, one located in Livingston, LA, one in Hanford, WA. The first generation was decommissioned near the end of 2010 and replaced by aLIGO which is expected to be fully operational around March 2015.

Intellectual merits: Our group developed new technologies for future implementation in aLIGO to improve the sensitivity and/or the reliability of the detector. These technologies include the development of a ring heater which is used in aLIGO to change the radius of curvature or the test masses in aLIGO. The radii of curvatures do not match perfectly the ideal radii of curvature due to manufacturing tolerances and also due to laser beam heating. Any mismatch will reduce the contrast in the Michelson interferometer and mode matching between the various optical resonators inside the interferometer. Heating the barrel of the test mass with a ring heater will create a temperature gradient across the mirror substrate and will change the radius of curvature of the front surface. The current aLIGO ring heaters consist of Nichrome wire wrapped around two semi-circular glass rods. These ring heaters showed some variances in the heating profiles which can lead to astigmatic test masses. The are also very brittle and a mechanical failure can lead to contamination of the test mass. Our ring heaters consist of Nichrome wire sandwiched between two alumina coated aluminum profiles. The side facing the test masses is also alumina coated to increase the emissivity. The use of alumina on aluminum instead of glass rods solves the mechanical failure risk while the high conductivity of aluminum together with some masking techniques allows to optimize the heating profile. 

A second developed technology addresses the phase modulation of the laser beam. The length and alignment sensing degrees of freedom of the mirrors inside the interferometer are sensed with a laser phase modulation/demodulation technique. aLIGO uses two different modulation frequencies to sense all five longitudinal and twelve alignment degrees of freedom. These modulations are currently applied in series which causes unwanted cross-products. We developed a parallel modulation scheme based on a Mach-Zehnder geometry which avoids these cross-products. It is currently not foreseen to implement this in aLIGO; the latest length and alignment sensing scheme is insensitive to these cross-products. 

aLIGO is expected to be limited in parts of the frequency spectrum by the Brownian motion of the atoms comprising the dielectric coatings of the test masses. This thermal noise is a function of frequency, beam size, and mechanical losses of the coatings. The physics of the mechanical losses is purely understood and the community relies on empirical searches for the best coating materials. However, empirical searches are typically limited to mechanical loss measurements and not optical thermal noise measurements. We developed a test chambers to measure coating thermal noise directly. We also developed a second test chamber which allows to change the temperature of the mirrors and coatings and investigate coating thermal noise at cryogenic temperatures. 

Our group also developed a scheme which allowed us to characterize the optical recycling cavities of advanced LIGO. This scheme measures the transversal mode spacing of different spatial cavity eigenmodes, deduce the Gouy phases inside the cavities, and compare them with expected Gouy phases based on radii of curvatures and distances between mirrors...
